post_text: Boise School District Is Idaho's Top District For National Merit Semifinalists — Boise, ID -- (9/09/2020) -- Officials from the National Merit Scholarship Corporation (NMSC) have announced the names of Idaho students selected as Semifinalists in the 66th Annual National Merit Scholarship Program. A total of 23 students from the Boise School District (the most of any Idaho school district) have been selected as Semifinalists, which represents 29% of Idaho's total number of 2021 National Merit Semifinalists (79). That's an impressive showing considering Boise School District enrolls approximately 9% of the public school students in Idaho. Thank you to our first responders! The COVID Help Now Line has resources specifically for first responders, including counseling and financial support.

#IdahoSTRONG is here to provide you with resources through the COVID-19 Help Now Line.

Our representatives will be waiting to help you through hardships caused by COVID-19. Call or text (986) 867-1073 or call Toll Free (866) 947-5186 to speak to a representative. COVID Help Now Line is staffed from 8am to 8pm Mountain Time, 7 days a week. Callers may also leave a message during off hours and receive a return call the following day. Responders do not classify, label, or diagnose people and no records are kept.

Multi-lingual representatives are available. Also visit www.ioem.idaho.gov/covidhelpnow to access resources electronically.

Dear Boise Schools Parents, Guardians and Staff,

In a statement made on July 23rd to our Board of Trustees, Central District Health indicated that we are currently in Category 3. Under those conditions, if school were to start today, our recommendation would be to have all students in a virtual space and not physically attending our schools.

Central District Health has also made it clear that no formal recommendation has been made for a reopening category based on our proposed start of school date of August 17th. CDH is developing metrics and will make a recommendation on August 3rd.

We understand that this is a very stressful situation. We will continue to work closely with Central District Health and area health professionals to ensure that we are making decisions based on the latest science and are in the best interests, safety and welfare of our students, staff and community.

Sincerely,
Boise School District Administration

Beth Corcoran Oppenheimer is with Jonathan Oppenheimer.
April 15 at 6:46 PM ·

I just wanted to say thank you to all Boise School District teachers for going above and beyond to support their students and their families. As a parent, I am truly grateful.

Yesterday, Mr. Josh McConnell from East Junior High spent an hour, one on one via google hangout, with Annabelle to support her with her math. I got to pop in for a second to thank him and he had the most positive and supportive attitude. He said he is so happy to be able to continue to support his students - especially during this time.

Our teachers are truly amazing! When you experience similar situations, please take a moment to reach out and thank them. They are trying to navigate this as much as we are and I honestly can't thank them enough. #everythingspossible #BSD #ThankATeacher

STUDENTS NAMED U.S. PRESIDENTIAL SCHOLARS CANDIDATES

A total of 20 Boise School District high school students have been selected as U.S. Presidential Scholars Program candidates. The U.S. Presidential Scholars Program was established in 1964, by executive order of the President, to recognize and honor some of our nation's most distinguished graduating high school seniors. Boise School District's 2020 U.S. Presidential Scholars Program candidates represent 43% of Idaho's total number of 2020 U.S. Presidential Scholars Program candidates (46). That's an impressive showing considering that Boise School District enrolls about 8% of the public school students in Idaho. Review the complete list of 2020 U.S. Presidential Scholars Program candidates. https://www2.ed.gov/programs/psp/2020/candidates.pdf

Young inventors participate in progressive levels of competitions, including three Regional events held across Idaho, culminating in a State Finals event.

In 2016, Rama Ramadhani came to Boise from Tanzania with his family. Knowing only his native language of Swahili, it was through soccer that he learned how to speak English.

During his junior year at Borah High School he was part of the junior varsity team where he scored 34 goals, earning him the Best Striker Award and a spot on the varsity team for his upcoming senior year.

Now as a senior, Rama plays forward on the Varsity Men’s Soccer team. Last week, he scored the game winning goal, beating Eagle High School 1-0, to claim Borah’s first district title in the program’s history.

“For me, it’s a dream to win district for my school in a place that I love,” Rama said excitedly. “Boise is my home now. I feel safe, I love living here and I enjoy playing soccer here.” #iamboise

“Rama is always smiling. You won’t find a happier young man than him. We are lucky to have Rama at Borah, said Tim Standlee, Borah High School Principal.

Borah High School is the top team headed into the 5A boys soccer state tournament. Good luck, Lions! Boise School District
